title: Modeling Tabular Boxes of Snacks with Slope Field

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in days.” The heading for row 2 is “S of t, in number of boxes of snacks remaining.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. S of t is 500. Column 2. t is 2. S of t is 340. Column 3. t is 5. S of t is 200. Column 4. t is 10. S of t is 20." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(days)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(number of boxes of snacks remaining)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>500</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>340</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>200</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student organization is selling boxes of snacks to raise money for a school trip. The student organization begins with <math alttext="500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> boxes of snacks and sells them over a ten-day period. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> days, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of boxes of snacks remaining to sell is modeled by a decreasing, twice-differentiable function <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="S of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="S prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="2 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in days.” The heading for row 2 is “S of t, in number of boxes of snacks remaining.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. S of t is 500. Column 2. t is 2. S of t is 340. Column 3. t is 5. S of t is 200. Column 4. t is 10. S of t is 20." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable align="center" columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(days)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(number of boxes of snacks remaining)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>500</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>340</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>200</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> A student organization is selling boxes of snacks to raise money for a school trip. The student organization begins with <math alttext="500" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> boxes of snacks and sells them over a ten-day period. For time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> days, <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of boxes of snacks remaining to sell is modeled by a decreasing, twice-differentiable function <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="S of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at various times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Using correct units, approximate <math alttext="S prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="2 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Explain the meaning of <math alttext="S prime of 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) It is known that <math alttext="S prime of 2, equals negative 55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>55</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals S of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Use a left Riemann sum with the three subintervals indicated by the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 10, of, S of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) Is the approximation from part (d) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 10, of, S of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(f) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 5, of, S prime of, open parenthesis, 2 t, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the total number of boxes of snacks remaining can also be modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume the weight of each box is <math alttext="7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces. Write an expression for the rate of change, in ounces per day, of the total weight of the boxes of snacks remaining at <math alttext="t equals 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days.

(h) Explain why the following slope field cannot represent the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to t, equals negative 0.2 y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
